overview_of_class:
Topics in Film/Video/Audio Production:
Web Convergence

This course is an introduction to web-based media through the practical use of web code, video, image editing, and animation. The course will explore different expressive media such as software, moving image, and performance, as well as show how these strategies can work in concert with each other online. Students will have the opportunity to conceptualize their own projects and select from a menu of approaches in order to execute them. Projects can include works created for the screen, the web, participation with web media at a specific site, or an event-based web work in public. Students will be evaluated through active participation, individual exercises, reading responses, presentations, and unit projects in group critique. The course is designed for students with no prior experience creating web media, although students with experience are welcome to enroll.

Learning Outcomes:
By the end of the quarter students should have a strong understanding of contemporary developments in web media and culture. Students should also have a working understanding of different tools for expressing their own ideas through web media as an individual production practice. Students should also be able to discern what tool and approach is appropriate and effective for a given concept, as well as how to seek out additional resources on their own.

Materials:
Readings will be provided as pdf or web documents.

overview_of_class:
Topics in Film/Video/Audio Production:
Introductory Game Studio

This course is a workshop for understanding the cultural context of video games through practical use of introductory game creation tools. The course aims to distinguish between how video games extend traditions of artistic exchange and how they offer novel and unexplored modes of communication unique to the medium. The course is designed to engender an active and critical perspective on what games are and how they relate to other cultural texts through analysis, discussion, production, and play. Students will have the opportunity to conceptualize their own game projects and select from a menu of approaches in order to resolve them. Students will be evaluated through active participation, individual exercises, reading responses, presentations, and unit projects in group critique. The course is designed for students with no prior game making experience, although students with experience are welcome to enroll.

LEARNING OUTCOMES
By the end of the quarter students should have a strong understanding of contemporary developments in game production. Students should also have a working understanding of different tools for game creation as well as how to choose an effective and meaningful tool for a particular concept.

MATERIALS
Readings will be provided as pdf or web documents.

overview_of_class:
RTVF 376-0 Sec. 22 Topics in Interactive Media: Alternative Reality Storytelling
Course Description

Mobile and location-based technologies (GPS, Google Earth, Google Maps) are offering artists, storytellers and filmmakers new meaning making opportunities and new challenges. The world surface has become a navigable canvas or stage where we can explore stories through physical walks. These walks can benefit from limitless interactivity of real life and all available technology. Location-based storytelling borrows conventions from game design, interactive narrative, improvisational theatre, sound and performance art, film, and more.

In this course, we will merge physical and virtual worlds and we will design fictional or non-fictional storytelling, game, art pieces based on walks that create or benefit from alternate, fragmented and virtual reality.

This production class will include tutorials about QR codes, ARIS (GPS based game design platform), Virtual Reality (HTC Vive, Tilt Brush, Google Sketch up). In addition to these tools participants can use any existing low or high technology such as USPS mailing system, email, augmented reality apps, SMS, tattoo and t-shirt design, Morse code, Skype, Google image search, sound recordings, film and video, photographs, music, flash mobs, live actors, etc. Class participants will design a short alternate reality experience that purposefully blurs reality and fiction and narrates a story. The final project will also include a short documentation video of this ephemeral experience. This video could become a portfolio piece.

Course Objectives
Along with the production of an alternate reality storytelling experience and demo video, we will read assigned theoretical text exploring the concept of the flâneur, psychogeographic drifts, theory of the dérive, affordances and limitations of interactive narratives, parallel universes, fragmentation of time and space. We will also explore seminal pieces (site-specific and location-based art, performance pieces, walks, music videos, collaborative games, alternate reality film promotion campaigns). Class participants will respond to the readings with written questions/answers. Participants will also make presentations about assigned artifacts.

Participants may choose to collaborate for their Final Project. No coding skills are needed. ?
